item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:39, topic:165714”]Well I got bored and rewrote it.

[code]import java.util.Scanner;

// Rewrote this for you haticks, just to show you, not a better way I guess, but a different way.
// Probably the easiest way too.
class Multi {

private static Scanner in;

public static void main(String[] args) {
    new Multi().multiTool();
}

private void multiTool() {
    in = new Scanner(System.in);
    System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.");
    System.out.println("This program has several tools that you may find useful.");
    System.out.println("Here are your choices: ");
    System.out.println("");
    System.out.println("1. Miles to kilometers.");
    System.out.println("2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.");
    System.out.println("3. Gallons to liters");
    System.out.println("4. Ounces to pounds.");
    System.out.println("6. Exit.");
    System.out.printf("Please type the number of the tool that you wish too use: ");
    handleChoice(in.nextInt());
}

private void handleChoice(int choice) {
    switch(choice) {
        case 1:
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.printf("Please enter the number of miles you would like to convert: ");
            int int1 = in.nextInt();
            int int2 = int1*8;
            int int3 = int2/5;
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.println(int1 + " miles is equal too " + int3 + " kilometers");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 2:
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.printf("Please enter Fahrenheit tempeture: ");
            int int4 = in.nextInt();
            int int5 = int4 - 32;
            int int6 = int5*5;
            int int7 = int6/9;
            System.out.println(int4 + " degrees Fharenheit converted to Celsius is: " + int7 + " degrees Celsius.");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 3:
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of gallons you wish to convert: ");
            int int8 = in.nextInt();
            double int9 = int8*3.7854;
            System.out.println(int8 + " gallons converted into liters is: " + int9 + " liters");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 4:
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of ounces you wish to convert: ");
            int int10 = in.nextInt();
            double int11 = int10/3.125;
            System.out.println(int10 + " ounces is equal to " + int11 + " pounds.");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 6:
            return;

        default:
            System.out.println("Incorrect choice..");
            break;
    }
}

private boolean again() {
    System.out.println("Type 1 to use again, 2 to exit.");
    switch(in.nextInt()) {
        case 1:
            return true;

        case 2:
            return false;

        default:
            System.out.println("Incorrect choice..");
            return false;
    }
}

}[/code][/quote]

  1. Isn’t using return right next to a break in a switch block that doesn’t have any code after it a bit redundant? If you would just let it continue, it would break the switch block and then return at the end of the method anyway.

  2. System.out.println("") could be replaced with System.out.println() or by prefixing a \n newline keystroke in the next message.

Read full topic

item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Well I got bored and rewrote it.

[code]import java.util.Scanner;

// Rewrote this for you haticks, just to show you, not a better way I guess, but a different way.
// Probably the easiest way too.
class Multi {

private static Scanner in;

public static void main(String[] args) {
    new Multi().multiTool();
}

private void multiTool() {
    in = new Scanner(System.in);
    System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.");
    System.out.println("This program has several tools that you may find useful.");
    System.out.println("Here are your choices: ");
    System.out.println("");
    System.out.println("1. Miles to kilometers.");
    System.out.println("2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.");
    System.out.println("3. Gallons to liters");
    System.out.println("4. Ounces to pounds.");
    System.out.println("6. Exit.");
    System.out.printf("Please type the number of the tool that you wish too use: ");
    handleChoice(in.nextInt());
}

private void handleChoice(int choice) {
    switch(choice) {
        case 1:
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.printf("Please enter the number of miles you would like to convert: ");
            int int1 = in.nextInt();
            int int2 = int1*8;
            int int3 = int2/5;
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.println(int1 + " miles is equal too " + int3 + " kilometers");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 2:
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.println("");
            System.out.printf("Please enter Fahrenheit tempeture: ");
            int int4 = in.nextInt();
            int int5 = int4 - 32;
            int int6 = int5*5;
            int int7 = int6/9;
            System.out.println(int4 + " degrees Fharenheit converted to Celsius is: " + int7 + " degrees Celsius.");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 3:
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of gallons you wish to convert: ");
            int int8 = in.nextInt();
            double int9 = int8*3.7854;
            System.out.println(int8 + " gallons converted into liters is: " + int9 + " liters");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 4:
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of ounces you wish to convert: ");
            int int10 = in.nextInt();
            double int11 = int10/3.125;
            System.out.println(int10 + " ounces is equal to " + int11 + " pounds.");
            if(again()) {
                this.multiTool();
            } else {
                return;
            }
            break;
        case 6:
            return;

        default:
            System.out.println("Incorrect choice..");
            break;
    }
}

private boolean again() {
    System.out.println("Type 1 to use again, 2 to exit.");
    switch(in.nextInt()) {
        case 1:
            return true;

        case 2:
            return false;

        default:
            System.out.println("Incorrect choice..");
            return false;
    }
}

}[/code]

item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“new Nub();, post:34, topic:165714”]fr33 c0nv3nt10ns pl0x…

[code]import java.util.*;

public class MultiTool
{
public static void main(String[] args) throws java.io.IOException
{
Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

	int userIn, int1, int2, int3, int4, int5, int6, int7, int8, int10;
	double dbl9, dbl11;
	
	int x = 1;
	
	System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.");
	System.out.println("This program has several tools that you may find useful.");
	System.out.println("Here are your choices: ");
	System.out.println("");
	System.out.println("1. Miles to kilometers.");
	System.out.println("2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.");
	System.out.println("3. Gallons to liters");
	System.out.println("4. Ounces to pounds.");
	System.out.println("5. Exit.");
	System.out.printf("Please type the number of the tool that you wish too use: ");
	userIn = Input.nextInt();
	
	if(userIn == 1)
	{
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.printf("Please enter the number of miles you would like to convert: ");
		int1 = Input.nextInt();
		int2 = int1 * 8;
		int3 = int2  / 5;
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println( int1 + " miles is eaqule too " + int3 + " kilometers");
		x = 1;
	}
	if(userIn == 2)
	{
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.printf("Please enter Fahrenheit tempeture: ");
		int4 = Input.nextInt();
		int5 = int4 - 32;
		int6 = int5 * 5;
		int7 = int6 / 9;
		System.out.println(int4 + " degrees Fharenheit converted to Celsius is: " + int7 + " degrees Celsius.");
		x = 1;
	}
	if(userIn == 3)
	{
		System.out.println(" ");
		System.out.println(" ");
		System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of gallons you wish to convert: ");
		int8 = Input.nextInt();
		dbl9 = int8 * 3.7854;
		System.out.println(int8 + " gallons converted into liters is: " +dbl9 + " liters");
		x = 1;
	}
	if(userIn == 4)
	{
		System.out.println(" ");
		System.out.println(" ");
		System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of ounces you wish to convert: ");
		int10 = Input.nextInt();
		dbl11 = int10 / 3.125;
		System.out.println(int10 + " ounces is eaqule to " + dbl11 + " pounds.");
		x = 1;
	}
	if(userIn == 5)
	{
		x = 0;
	}
	
	while(x == 1)
	{
		System.out.println("_______________________________________________________________________");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("Here are your choices..");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("1. Miles to kilometers.");
		System.out.println("2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.");
		System.out.println("3. Gallons to liters");
		System.out.println("4. Ounces to pounds.");
		System.out.println("5. Exit.");
		System.out.printf("Please type the number of the tool that you wish too use: ");
		UserIn = Input.nextInt();
	}
}

}[/code][/quote]
Next time you are going to try and prove your superiority over someone who is just starting, at least do it the right way.

[code]import java.util.*;

public class MultiTool
{
public static void main(String[] args) throws java.io.IOException
{
Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

	int userIn, int1, int2, int3, int4, int5, int6, int7, int8, int10;
	double dbl9, dbl11;
	
	int x = 1;
	
	System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.");

item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

Good job on your first java program, its a horrible case of spaghetti-code but nonetheless it compiles

Heres kinda what it should look like not to mention the fact that utilizing the java OOP concept would be a good idea:

(psuedocode)

import java.util.*;

public class MultiTool {
	public static void main(String[] args) throws java.io.IOException {
		Scanner Input = new Scanner(System.in);
		int UserIn, int1, int2, int3, int4, int5, int6, int7, int8, int10;
		double int9, int11;
		double int11;
		int x = 1;

		System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.\nThis program has several tools that you may find useful.\nHere are your choices:\n\n1. Miles to kilometers\n2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.\n3. Gallons to liters\n4. Ounces to pounds.\n5. Exit.\nlease type the number of the tool that you wish too use: ");
		UserIn = Input.nextInt();

			if(UserIn == 1){
				System.out.println("");
				System.out.println("");
				System.out.printf("Please enter the number of miles you would like to convert: ");
				int1 = Input.nextInt();
				int2 = int1 * 8;
				int3 = int2  / 5;
				System.out.println("");
				System.out.println( int1 + " miles is eaqule too " + int3 + " kilometers");
				x = 1;

			}
			if(UserIn == 2){
				System.out.println("");
				System.out.println("");
				System.out.printf("Please enter Fahrenheit tempeture: ");
				int4 = Input.nextInt();
				int7 = ((int4 - 32) * 5) / 9
				System.out.println(int4 + " degrees Fharenheit converted to Celsius is: " + int7 + " degrees Celsius.");
				x = 1;
			}
			if(UserIn == 3){
				System.out.println(" ");
				System.out.println(" ");
				System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of gallons you wish to convert: ");
				int8 = Input.nextInt();
				int9 = int8 * 3.7854;
				System.out.println(int8 + " gallons converted into liters is: " +int9 + " liters");
				x = 1;
			}
			if(UserIn == 4){
				System.out.println(" ");
				System.out.println(" ");
				System.out.printf("Please enter the amount of ounces you wish to convert: ");
				int10 = Input.nextInt();
				int11 = int10 / 3.125;
				System.out.println(int10 + " ounces is eaqule to " + int11 + " pounds.");
				x = 1;
			}
			if(UserIn == 5){
				x = 0;

			}
			while(x == 1){
				System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.\nThis program has several tools that you may find useful.\nHere are your choices:\n\n1. Miles to kilometers\n2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.\n3. Gallons to liters\n4. Ounces to pounds.\n5. Exit.\nlease type the number of the tool that you wish too use: ");
				UserIn = Input.nextInt();
			}
	}
	
}

Also check out the swing library, its pretty simple and there’s alot of resources.

Read full topic

item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:29, topic:165714”][quote author=meiscooldude link=topic=224789.msg1952898#msg1952898 date=1198619271]

You shouldn’t need those methods to be public in a standalone application.

alright… i’ll edit it… well… i don’t see any point in confusing him with using private methods… that gets into objects… and if i take away the public… they are automatically public… soo… idk

Merry Christmas Everyone!!!

Ohh, I believe the formula you put for converting Ounces to pounds was incorrect.
[/quote]

If you take away the public they are not public, private or protected. Also, access modifiers have just as much to do with objects as the Java language. And now is a better time for him to learn than later. Because later means procrastination and that means laziness which leads to not learning what he could have a long time prior.[/quote]later doesn’t mean procrastination, you do grade 1 before you do grade 2… grade 2 before you do grade 3… building your knowledge

Read full topic

item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“meiscooldude, post:28, topic:165714”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=224789.msg1952894#msg1952894 date=1198619139]
You shouldn’t need those methods to be public in a standalone application.
[/quote]

alright… i’ll edit it… well… i don’t see any point in confusing him with using private methods… that gets into objects… and if i take away the public… they are automatically public… soo… idk

Merry Christmas Everyone!!!

Ohh, I believe the formula you put for converting Ounces to pounds was incorrect.[/quote]

If you take away the public they are not public, private or protected. Also, access modifiers have just as much to do with objects as the Java language. And now is a better time for him to learn than later. Because later means procrastination and that means laziness which leads to not learning what he could have a long time prior.

Read full topic

@meiscooldude wrote:

Taharok:

You shouldn’t need those methods to be public in a standalone application.

alright… i’ll edit it… well… i don’t see any point in confusing him with using private methods… that gets into objects… and if i take away the public… they are automatically public… soo… idk

Merry Christmas Everyone!!!

Ohh, I believe the formula you put for converting Ounces to pounds was incorrect.

item.title: Finished first java program
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“meiscooldude, post:26, topic:165714”]Ok, I totally Rewrote your little program, Look and Learn!!!

[code]/**

  • MultiTool
  • by: haticks
  • edited by: Meiscooldude

*/

//all classes should have commments… everywhere!!!

import java.util.*;

public class MultiTool
{

static Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);   //notice how input is not capitalized, and it is declared outside of the main so other methods can use it

public static void main(String[] args)// throws java.io.IOException
{

    boolean canRun = true;                    //acording to (my) java convention, Only Class names should be capitalized.
    int userIn = 0;
    
    System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.");
	System.out.println("This program has several tools that you may find useful.");
	System.out.println();
	
	while(canRun == true)
	{
		System.out.println("Here are your choices: ");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("1. Miles to kilometers.");
		System.out.println("2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.");
		System.out.println("3. Gallons to liters");
		System.out.println("4. Ounces to pounds.");
		System.out.println("5. Exit.");
		System.out.print("Please type the number of the tool that you wish too use: "); //instead of printf(String) i will use just print(String)
		userIn = input.nextInt();
		
		switch(userIn) //instead of big if else blocks, use a switch.
		{
			case 1:   milesToKilo();
				break;
					
			case 2:   fahrenToCel();
				break;
					
			case 3:   gallonsToLiters();
				break;
					
			case 4:   ouncesToPounds();
				break;
					
			case 5:   canRun = false;
				System.out.println();
				break;
					
			default:  System.out.println();
				System.out.println("!!!!!!!!!!!");
				System.out.println("!Bad input!");
				System.out.println("!!!!!!!!!!!");
		}
		if(canRun == true)
		{
			System.out.println("_______________________________________________________________________");
			System.out.println();
		}
	}
}
	
public static void milesToKilo()
{
	System.out.println();
	System.out.println();
	System.out.print("Please enter the number of miles you would like to convert: ");
	double miles = input.nextDouble();  //I am using doubles because they are more acurate when deviding
	double kilo =(miles * 8)/5;
	System.out.println();
	System.out.println( miles + " miles is eaqule too " + kilo + " kilometers");	
}

public static void fahrenToCel()
{
	System.out.println();
	System.out.println();
	System.out.print("Please enter Fahrenheit tempeture: ");
	double fahren = input.nextDouble();  // Notice how i declare the variables and initalize them in the same statement
	double celsius = (fahren - 32) * 5 / 9;   // I've also put all the calculations into one statement
	System.out.println(fahren + " degrees Fahrenheit converted to Celsius is: " + celsius + " degrees Celsius.");
}

public static void gallonsToLiters()
{
	System.out.println();  
	System.out.println();
	System.out.print("Please enter the amount of gallons you wish to convert: ");
	double gallons = input.nextDouble(); //also the variables have easily readable names, so you could identify them just by looking
	double liters = gallons * 3.7854;
	System.out.println(gallons + " gallons converted into liters is: " +liters + " liters");
}

public static void ouncesToPounds()
{
	System.out.println(" "); // System.out.println(String) has been overloaded, you don't need a string in it
	System.out.println();    // This line does the same as the line above
	System.out.print("Please enter the amount of ounces you wish to convert: ");
	double ounces = input.nextDouble();
	double pounds = ounces / 3.125;
	System.out.println(ounces + " ounces is eaqule to " + pounds + " pounds.");
}

}
[/code]

If anyone sees anythign wrong… tell me, I did’nt really go over the formulas, Just went by what he put, and what i knew from memory.[/quote]

You shouldn’t need those methods to be public in a standalone application.

Read full topic

@meiscooldude wrote:

Ok, I totally Rewrote your little program, Look and Learn!!!

[code]/**

  • MultiTool
  • by: haticks
  • edited by: Meiscooldude

*/

//all classes should have commments… everywhere!!!

import java.util.*;

public class MultiTool
{

static Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);   //notice how input is not capitalized, and it is declared outside of the main so other methods can use it

public static void main(String[] args)// throws java.io.IOException
{

    boolean canRun = true;                    //acording to (my) java convention, Only Class names should be capitalized.
    int userIn = 0;
    
    System.out.println("Welcome to MultiTool.");
	System.out.println("This program has several tools that you may find useful.");
	System.out.println();
	
	while(canRun == true)
	{
		System.out.println("Here are your choices: ");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("1. Miles to kilometers.");
		System.out.println("2. Fahrenheit to Celsius.");
		System.out.println("3. Gallons to liters");
		System.out.println("4. Ounces to pounds.");
		System.out.println("5. Exit.");
		System.out.print("Please type the number of the tool that you wish too use: "); //instead of printf(String) i will use just print(String)
		userIn = input.nextInt();
		
		switch(userIn) //instead of big if else blocks, use a switch.
		{
			case 1:   milesToKilo();
				break;
					
			case 2:   fahrenToCel();
				break;
					
			case 3:   gallonsToLiters();
				break;
					
			case 4:   ouncesToPounds();
				break;
					
			case 5:   canRun = false;
				System.out.println();
				break;
					
			default:  System.out.println();
				System.out.println("!!!!!!!!!!!");
				System.out.println("!Bad input!");
				System.out.println("!!!!!!!!!!!");
		}
		if(canRun == true)
		{
			System.out.println("_______________________________________________________________________");
			System.out.println();
		}
	}
}
	
public static void milesToKilo()
{
	System.out.println();
	System.out.println();
	System.out.print("Please enter the number of miles you would like to convert: ");
	double miles = input.nextDouble();  //I am using doubles because they are more acurate when deviding
	double kilo =(miles * 8)/5;
	System.out.println();
	System.out.println( miles + " miles is eaqule too " + kilo + " kilometers");	
}

public static void fahrenToCel()
{
	System.out.println();
	System.out.println();
	System.out.print("Please enter Fahrenheit tempeture: ");
	double fahren = input.nextDouble();  // Notice how i declare the variables and initalize them in the same statement
	double celsius = (fahren - 32) * 5 / 9;   // I've also put all the calculations into one statement
	System.out.println(fahren + " degrees Fahrenheit converted to Celsius is: " + celsius + " degrees Celsius.");
}

public static void gallonsToLiters()
{
	System.out.println();  
	System.out.println();
	System.out.print("Please enter the amount of gallons you wish to convert: ");
	double gallons = input.nextDouble(); //also the variables have easily readable names, so you could identify them just by looking
	double liters = gallons * 3.7854;
	System.out.println(gallons + " gallons converted into liters is: " +liters + " liters");
}

public static void ouncesToPounds()
{
	System.out.println(" "); // System.out.println(String) has been overloaded, you don't need a string in it
	System.out.println();    // This line does the same as the line above
	System.out.print("Please enter the amount of ounces you wish to convert: ");
	double ounces = input.nextDouble();
	double pounds = ounces / 3.125;
	System.out.println(ounces + " ounces is eaqule to " + pounds + " pounds.");
}

}
[/code]

If anyone sees anythign wrong… tell me, I did’nt really go over the formulas, Just went by what he put, and what i knew from memory.
